Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The developmental genetics of floral size variation in Saltugilia (Polemoniaceae): Linking cellular phenotypes, genetics, floral size, and pollinator shifts
Award.AbstractNarration:
The interactions between plants and their pollinators has been gaining increased attention recently due to the recognition of extensive pollinator loss due to anthropogenic activities. One trait that is important for pollinator success is flower size. This project will investigate the cellular and genetic bases of flower size as it relates to selection by pollinators in the phlox family of flowering plants (Polemoniaceae). The goals of this study are: 1) determine the phylogenetic relationships among members of genus Saltugilia, 2) measure cell area of petal epidermal cells in developing flowers using microscopy techniques, 3) identify and isolate the possible genes responsible for the control of flower size based on data from other species, 4) determine the expression profiles of these genes in developing flowers and in species with different pollinators, and 5) demonstrate the function of these genes in regulating floral size.

This research will provide the co-PI with training in current genetic and cellular techniques, in addition to training two undergraduates in laboratory techniques. Hands-on modules for high school students will be developed to teach common laboratory techniques such as DNA extractions and polymerase chain reaction. High school teachers will be trained in these protocols to increase the implementation of the modules.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the most intriguing evolutionary patterns is the relationship between flowers and their pollinators, a coevolutionary phenomenon that has significant implications for both ecology and agriculture.  In this project, we investigated the cellular and genetic foundations of variation in flower shape and size as they related to differences in pollinators. For this project, we generated well-resolved relationships of the members of Saltugilia, a genus of 6 taxa in the angiosperm family Polemoniaceae, using 54 nuclear genes and sequence data from the chloroplast genome. This analysis generated the framework necessary to understand the directionality of shifts in flower size, in this case from smaller flowers to larger flowers. Using a new protocol that we developed, we measured and counted epidermal cells in flowers of different developmental stages from all six collected accessions in Saltugilia, as well as many species in the closely related genus Gilia. We identified and measured four unique cell types shared in all accessions of Saltugilia and determined the proportion of each cell type throughout development of the flowers to ask whether flower size is determined by differences in cell number or cell size or both. In general, the size of the cells is the larger contributor to overall flower size. In the two species of Saltugilia with the largest flowers, however, cell number also changes, with these two species having close to 200 more cells per flower than the other species, with the majority of these additional cells comprising regions of the corolla tube.  Thus, cell number, cell type, and cell size all play roles in differentiating small and large flowers in Saltugilia.

To investigate the genetic underpinnings of flower size differences, we employed a comparative transcriptomic approach.  This method sequences all genes present at a given developmental stage. By comparing developmental stages among all taxa of Saltugilia, we were able to identify four genes that fit into the hypothesized gene network for organ size: two cell wall modification genes, a growth-promoting factor gene, and a sucrose-producing gene. In addition, we identified four candidate genes from Arabidopsis that have been shown to affect flower size, including an inhibitor of cell division, an inhibitor of cell elongation, and two elongation enhancer genes. Some of these genes have higher expression rates earlier in development, while others are more highly expressed in the mature flowers.

The results generated during the life of this award have started to shed light on the genetics of flower size differences in a non-model system. We show correlations between gene expression and cell size differences, but future functional work is necessary to determine exactly what these genes are doing in Saltugilia. Additional broader impacts for this award include providing research opportunities for four undergraduates in the lab, as well as poster presentations for two of the undergraduates. Additionally, three of the four undergraduate students are co-authors on published and soon-to-be-submitted manuscripts from these projects. In addition to the research, a summer forensic botany module was conducted during Summer 2014 in conjunction with the University of Florida Center for Precollegiate Education and Training. A total of 48 Florida high school students participated in the forensic module, giving them experience in extracting DNA, setting up PCR (polymerase chain reaction) runs, gel electrophoresis, and using light microscopes. In addition to the forensic module, a phylogenetics and plant/pollinator interactions module that the Co-PI created was also implemented with a different group of high school students. A total of 250 high school students and 10 high school teachers participated in both modules combined, with the phylogenetics module also leading to a publication in Cell Biology and Education.
